newsitem.title: BRAZIL: WHEAT HARVEST BEGINS IN BRAZIL'S PARANA STATE.
newsitem.headline: WHEAT HARVEST BEGINS IN BRAZIL'S PARANA STATE.

text.p: Scattered harvesting has begun in Brazil's key wheat producing state of Parana and the quality of the wheat is mostly good, said Norberto Ortigara, head of the Department of Rural Economy (Deral) in Parana.
"Harvesting has started in some places in the last few days, but statistically it's insignificant," said Ortigara.

Parana, which accounts for some 60 percent of Brazil's total wheat production, is forecast to produce between 1.6 and 1.76 million tonnes in the 1997/98 crop year (August/July), down from 1.98 million tonnes in 1996/97.
Planted area fell 16 percent to 860,000 hectares.

Despite a drought from March 15 to May 20 which delayed planting, the crop recovered thanks to regular rainfall in May and productivity was seen at 1,950 kg per hectare, just over the 1,930 kg per hectare registered last harvest, Ortigara said.
"Most of the harvest is in very good condition," he said.
Some 46 percent of the crop was in the vegetative stage, 26 percent was flowering and 25 percent was in the pod-filling phase, while around two percent was maturing.
The harvest is due to begin in earnest at the end of August. In Rio Grande do Sul, the second largest producing state, planting begins 45 days later and harvesting starts in late September.
Rio Grande was set to produce 780,000 tonnes in 1997/98, down 22 percent from the previous harvest, independent consultant Safras e Mercado said.
Safras predicted Brazil would have to import 5.55 million tonnes of wheat in the coming crop year against 5.30 million tonnes in 1996/97, with most imports likely to come from Argentina.
